title: Julianna Margulies stuns in one-shoulder black dress as co-host of Project ALS gala in NYC
text:
She is best known to many of her her fans for playing Nurse Carol Hathaway on the long-running medical-drama series ER, and in the lead role of Alicia Florrick in the legal drama The Good Wife.

And on Wednesday, Julianna Margulies lent her time and support when she co-hosted -- Project ALS Presents Tomorrow Is Tonight 21st Anniversary Celebration -- with Ben Stiller.

The festive gala was a celebration of Project ALS progress toward understanding and effectively treating ALS (amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) and related brain diseases.

Shining star: Julianna Margulies stunned in a one-shoulder black-patterned dress at the Project ALS Tomorrow Is Tonight 21st Anniversary Celebration

The actress, 53, stunned in a one-shoulder black-patterned dress that glistened under the intense lights from the photographers.

She matched it with a pair of silver strapped heels and wore her raven tress long with a some added waves and her hair pulled back off her face.

The New York native was proud to share the spotlight of the red carpet with her lawyer husband Keith Lieberthal.

He looked classy decked out in a blue-grey, two-piece suit, white shirt and red-patterned tie.

Sharing the spotlight: The former ER star co-hosted the event with Ben Stiller

Quality time: The actress, 53, arrived at the event with husband and lawyer Keith Lieberthal, 42

Honing it in: The actress also wore a pair of silver strapped heels and styled her raven tress long with a some added waves and her hair pulled back off her face

Before the event, Margulies also stopped to pose for the cameras with author Valerie Estess, who co-founded Project ALS with her sisters Jenifer and Meredith.

Along with celebrating 21 years Of Project ALS, the evening also honored families touched by the nervous system disease, for their leadership, compassion and generosity of spirit.

Plus there was an update by Project ALS' Clinical Researchers on the new groundbreaking research and news.

Making her mark: Margulies is best know for her television roles on ER and The Good Wife

Project ALS requires that its funded researchers communicate regularly, share data openly, meet project milestones, and submit progress reports twice annually.

The organization's research advisory board, which gathers preeminent neurologists and neuroscientists across academia and industry, evaluates that progress regularly.

In 20 years, Project ALS has raised over $90 million, directing between 80-93% annually to research programs.
description: Julianna Marguiles stunned in a one-shoulder black dress the glistened under the lights as co-host of the Project ALS gala in New York City on Wednesday.
